channel.title: R Markdown on Jack's Blog
channel.description: Recent content in R Markdown on Jack's Blog

item.title: DT::datatable seasoned with javascript
item.description: Indiana Coronavirus Case Model I’ve been working on a statistical model for predicting daily COVID-19 case counts in Indiana. I gathered data from 7 places: https://github.com/RamiKrispin/coronavirus https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/2393.htm https://trends.google.com/trends/?geo=US https://evictionlab.org/ https://www.gstatic.com/covid19/mobility/Global_Mobility_Report.csv https://www.wfyi.org/ https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/rural-urban-commuting-area-codes/ I also manually included the “phases” for Holcomb’s Back on Track plan. Results My model is still in development, but I’ve made some progress. Set aside the last 28 days as testing data and trained my model on the remaining data.

item.title: Tidy Tuesday 9-29-2020
item.description: Load Packages beyonce: Load Beyonce themed color palettes gridExtra: To arrange visualizations knitr: For nice data frame printing rvest: For webscraping scales: To help with plots tidytext: To do text processing tidyverse: For data cleaning and plotting tidytuesdayR: To load the Tidy Tuesday data library(beyonce) library(gridExtra) library(knitr) library(rvest) library(scales) library(tidytext) library(tidytuesdayR) library(tidyverse) Load Data Following the instructions on the Tidy Tuesday Github: tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2020-09-29') ## --- Compiling #TidyTuesday Information for 2020-09-29 ---- ## --- There are 4 files available --- ## --- Starting Download --- ## ## Downloading file 1 of 4: `beyonce_lyrics.

item.title: DT::datatable seasoned with javascript
item.description: /* This will get a row ID via our data table and modify a bunch of HTML based on that row */ chop = function(id) { var row = chopped[id]; document.getElementById("episode_name").innerHTML = row["episode_name"] + ": " + row["air_date"]; document.getElementById("episode_notes").innerHTML = row["episode_notes"]; document.getElementById("judge1").innerHTML = row["judge1"]; document.getElementById("judge2").innerHTML = row["judge2"]; document.getElementById("judge3").innerHTML = row["judge3"]; document.getElementById("appetizer").innerHTML = row["appetizer"]; document.getElementById("entree").innerHTML = row["entree"]; document.getElementById("dessert").innerHTML = row["dessert"]; document.getElementById("chef1").innerHTML = row["contestant1"] + ": "

item.title: Reproducible ICD Conversion With ATHENA and R
item.description: Why Bother? If you work with diagnosis data, you’re likely to encounter ICD codes. ICD (Internal Classification of Diseases) is a globally used set codes that hierarchically classifies diagnoses, symptoms, and other clinical observations. Since the adoption of the Electronic Health Records (EHR), the primary revision of ICD in use ICD-9. At least, that was so until October 1st, 2015, when the United States made a nationwide switch to ICD-10.

item.title: How To: Create a Practice OMOP Dataset in R
item.description: Introduction The use of electronic health record (EHR) data is common and often necessary in clinical research. These data can be cumbersome and complicated, yet inaccessible due to privacy laws. My goal in this post is to set the reader up with a “fake” clinical dataset so that they can learn the ins and out of EHR data and feel more prepared when they encounter the real thing.
